description: From French marron (“feral; fugitive”, adjective), from Spanish cimarrón (“fugitive, wild, feral”); see that entry for more.

entries.meaning: Associated with Maroon culture, communities or peoples.
examples: In her discussion of Michelle Cliff's Abeng, a novel that historicizes maroon culture and the Jamaican warrior heroine Nanny of the Maroons, Francoise Lionnet examines linguistic “metissage”  […]

entries.meaning: An escaped negro of the Caribbean and the Americas or a descendant of such a person. [from 17th c.]
examples: Further north a Maroon community in the Bahoruco Mountains thrived for eighty-five years, until the French proposed a truce under the terms of which the Maroons would be permitted to form an independent clan.

entries.meaning: A castaway; a person who has been marooned. [from 19th c.]

verbs.description: maroon (third-person singular simple present maroons, present participle marooning, simple past and past participle marooned)

entries.meaning: To abandon in a remote, desolate place, as on a desert island.

description: French marron (“chestnut; brown”), from Italian marrone (“chestnut; brown”). Compare Spanish marrón.

adjectives.description: maroon (comparative more maroon, superlative most maroon)

entries.meaning: A rich dark red, somewhat brownish, color.

description: Unknown. Possibly related to the sense “castaway” (etymology 1), or owing to the fact that the color of a fired flare was commonly red (etymology 2).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A rocket-propelled firework or skyrocket, often one used as a signal (e.g. to summon the crew of a lifeboat or warn of an air raid).
examples: On Sunday afternoon a serious firework explosion occurred in Lambeth, whereby three persons were seriously injured. Two lads  […]  purchased a firework called a “maroon”, which is a bomb consisting of a small ball of string covered with a red composition. It is loaded with gunpowder, and there is also a fuse attached.

description: From an intentional mispronunciation of the word moron used by the cartoon character Bugs Bunny.
